title: Boundaries & Independence
description: Navigate the balance between togetherness and individual identity.

questions.text: How do I feel about alone time in our relationship?
choices: I need regular time to myself
I like some solo time but prefer togetherness
I'd rather do most things together
I need alone time but feel guilty asking

therapeutic.rationale: Alone time needs reflect introversion/extroversion and self-definition. Regular-needers require solitude for energy; moderate-needers appreciate balance; flexible people adapt; together-preferrers charge through connection; guilty-askers need but suppress the need. Healthy relationships honor both partners' autonomy needs without personalizing them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different alone-time needs require negotiation, not compromise of needs. The regular-needer shouldn't feel guilty; the together-preferrer shouldn't feel rejected. Both needs are valid and can coexist.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared alone-time preferences make navigating togetherness-autonomy natural. You'll both want similar amounts of space.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much alone time do you need? Are you getting it? What happens when you don't get enough—or get too much?

questions.text: What's something I need to keep just for myself?
choices: Some friendships outside our relationship
Hobbies or interests you don't share
Personal thoughts and processing space
Nothing—I want to share everything

therapeutic.rationale: Healthy relationships include individual identity preservation. Separate friendships maintain social diversity; solo hobbies preserve individual interests; private thoughts maintain internal space; separate finances preserve autonomy; total-sharers blur boundaries (which can be healthy or enmeshed). Partners should support each other's individual selfhood, not erase it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different boundary needs are normal and healthy. Your partner's need for separate friendships isn't a rejection; your need for privacy isn't secretiveness. Respect what each person needs to remain a distinct self.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared boundary preferences suggest similar comfort with closeness and autonomy. You're aligned on how much individual space feels right.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need to keep as 'yours' in the relationship? Does your partner respect this? What would threaten this boundary?

questions.text: How do I feel when you make decisions without consulting me?
choices: Fine—I trust your judgment
Depends on how big the decision is
I prefer to be consulted on most things
Hurt—I want to be included

therapeutic.rationale: Decision inclusion expectations reveal partnership assumptions. Trust-first types give autonomy freely; size-dependent types apply context; consultation-preferrers want voice; hurt-feelers need inclusion for security; mixed-feelers evaluate situationally. Understanding where your partner falls helps you know when to include them versus act independently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different inclusion needs require explicit discussion. The trust-first type may exclude the consultation-preferrer accidentally; the inclusion-needer may feel smothered by the autonomy-giver's consultation. Clarify expectations.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared inclusion expectations make decision-making flow naturally. You both expect the same level of consultation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner decides things without asking? What decisions must include you? What's truly okay to do independently?

questions.text: What's most important to me about maintaining my individuality?
choices: Staying connected to my own interests
Having my own opinions and voice
Having personal goals beyond our relationship
Being seen as 'me' not just 'us'

therapeutic.rationale: Individual identity preservation takes different forms. Interest-maintainers protect hobbies; voice-maintainers protect perspective; relationship-maintainers protect social connections; goal-maintainers protect personal ambition; separate-identity maintainers protect self-concept. Healthy couples support each other's distinct personhood rather than merging into one undifferentiated unit.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different individuality priorities reveal different aspects of self you each need to protect. Support what your partner needs to remain fully themselves.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared individuality priorities suggest you both value the same aspects of separate selfhood. Protect this together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's essential to maintaining your individual identity? Does being in this relationship support or threaten your sense of self?

questions.text: How do I feel about sharing everything with you?
choices: I want to—openness feels right
Mostly open, with a few private areas
I need some things to stay mine
It feels vulnerable but important

therapeutic.rationale: Sharing comfort levels reflect attachment and boundary styles. Total-sharers feel closeness through disclosure; mostly-open types balance connection and privacy; privacy-needers protect internal space; vulnerable-sharers feel exposed but recognize value; strugglers are still calibrating. Healthy sharing is mutually agreed upon, not demanded or resented.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different sharing comforts require respect, not pressure. The total-sharer shouldn't demand disclosure; the private person shouldn't be pushed. Find a sharing level that works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sharing comfort makes openness negotiations natural. You're aligned on how much disclosure feels right.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much do you want to share with your partner? Is there pressure to share more or less than feels comfortable? What would your ideal sharing level be?
